channel.title: World : NPR
channel.description: NPR world news, international art and culture, world business and financial markets, world economy, and global trends in health, science and technology. Subscribe to the World Story of the Day podcast and RSS feed.

item.title: Money for Ukraine is losing Republican support in Congress
item.description: In Congress, there is a broad agreement over the funding for Israel, but the money for Ukraine is losing Republican support.

content:encoded.#cdata-section: In Congress, there is a broad agreement over the funding for Israel, but the money for Ukraine is losing Republican support.

item.dc:creator: Franco Ordo√±ez

item.title: Families of hostages held by Hamas conclude march to Netanyahu's office
item.description: In Israel, families of some of the more than 200 hostages taken by Hamas during its deadly Oct. 7 attack concluded a march across the country from Tel Aviv to the prime minister's office in Jerusalem.

content:encoded.#cdata-section: In Israel, families of some of the more than 200 hostages taken by Hamas during its deadly Oct. 7 attack concluded a march across the country from Tel Aviv to the prime minister's office in Jerusalem.

item.dc:creator: Peter Kenyon

item.title: The Vatican broadens public access to an ancient Roman necropolis
item.description: In the past, tours of the ancient burial site were generally only granted to approved academics, students and other specialists.

content:encoded.#cdata-section:
In the past, tours of the ancient burial site were generally only granted to approved academics, students and other specialists.

(Image credit: Gregorio Borgia/AP)

item.dc:creator: Chloe Veltman

item.title: A violist memorializes lost voices at Terezin concentration camp
item.description: Scott Simon talks with violist Mark Ludwig about his efforts to preserve - and play - the music written by some of the many musicians imprisoned and killed at the Terezin concentration camp.

content:encoded.#cdata-section: Scott Simon talks with violist Mark Ludwig about his efforts to preserve - and play - the music written by some of the many musicians imprisoned and killed at the Terezin concentration camp.

item.dc:creator: Scott Simon

item.title: Voters in Argentina will select a new president
item.description: The two candidates in Argentina's Presidential runoff are almost neck and neck in an election where the economic crisis dominates the race.

content:encoded.#cdata-section: The two candidates in Argentina's Presidential runoff are almost neck and neck in an election where the economic crisis dominates the race.

item.dc:creator: Carrie Kahn

item.title: Members of Israeli and Palestinian communities discuss compassion
item.description: Israeli Jews, Arab citizens of Israel, and Palestinians speak about the pain they share and their desire for a better way forward, one that releases them from a prison of retribution and violence.

content:encoded.#cdata-section: Israeli Jews, Arab citizens of Israel, and Palestinians speak about the pain they share and their desire for a better way forward, one that releases them from a prison of retribution and violence.

item.dc:creator: Ari Daniel

item.title: The stars of "Fallen Leaves" talk comedy and romance in the new Finnish film
item.description: Scott Simon talks with actors Alma Poysti and Jussi Vatanen about their new film, "Fallen Leaves." They play an unlikely couple in this Finnish movie, which won a Jury Prize at Cannes.

content:encoded.#cdata-section: Scott Simon talks with actors Alma Poysti and Jussi Vatanen about their new film, "Fallen Leaves." They play an unlikely couple in this Finnish movie, which won a Jury Prize at Cannes.

item.dc:creator: Scott Simon

item.title: Unpacking developments from this year's APEC
item.description: President Biden's meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping was the big news from the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation's forum. Scott Simon and John Ruwitch discuss other developments from the week.

content:encoded.#cdata-section: President Biden's meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping was the big news from the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation's forum. Scott Simon and John Ruwitch discuss other developments from the week.

item.dc:creator: John Ruwitch

item.title: Week in politics: Congress halts a government shutdown
item.description: A government shutdown is averted for now, yet tempers flared on Capitol Hill before lawmakers left town this week. Meanwhile, President Biden met with Chinese leader Xi Jinping.

content:encoded.#cdata-section: A government shutdown is averted for now, yet tempers flared on Capitol Hill before lawmakers left town this week. Meanwhile, President Biden met with Chinese leader Xi Jinping.

item.dc:creator: Ron Elving

item.title: Israel military evacuates Gaza's largest hospital
item.description: Israel's military is evacuating Gaza's largest hospital, which has been the center of the war for weeks. Meanwhile, negotiations continue with Hamas over the release of hostages.

content:encoded.#cdata-section: Israel's military is evacuating Gaza's largest hospital, which has been the center of the war for weeks. Meanwhile, negotiations continue with Hamas over the release of hostages.

item.dc:creator: Lauren Frayer

item.title: In tight election race, Argentina to choose between far-right and Peronist candidates
item.description: Sunday's vote is between a far-right libertarian and the current economy minister. The winner will confront challenges such as triple-digit inflation, poverty and an increasingly polarized population.

content:encoded.#cdata-section:
Sunday's vote is between a far-right libertarian and the current economy minister. The winner will confront challenges such as triple-digit inflation, poverty and an increasingly polarized population.

(Image credit: Luis Robayo/AFP via Getty Images)

item.dc:creator: Carrie Kahn

item.title: Israel told Palestinians to evacuate to southern Gaza ‚Äî and stepped up attacks there
item.description: Satellite imagery shows a steady increase in the number of buildings destroyed in middle and southern Gaza. Most damage appeared after Oct. 13, when Israel's military urged evacuation from the north.

content:encoded.#cdata-section:
Satellite imagery shows a steady increase in the number of buildings destroyed in middle and southern Gaza. Most damage appeared after Oct. 13, when Israel's military urged evacuation from the north.

(Image credit: Daniel Wood/NPR)

item.dc:creator: Ruth Sherlock

item.title: A new report says Belarus has assisted Russia in abducting Ukrainian children
item.description: The State Department and the Yale School of Public Health's Humanitarian Research Lab release new information about Belarus's "complicity in and support for" Russia's abduction of Ukrainian children.

content:encoded.#cdata-section: The State Department and the Yale School of Public Health's Humanitarian Research Lab release new information about Belarus's "complicity in and support for" Russia's abduction of Ukrainian children.

item.dc:creator: Michele Kelemen

item.title: Finding space for satire in the Israel-Hamas war
item.description: Satire has found a role amidst the tragedy of the Israel-Hamas war.

content:encoded.#cdata-section: Satire has found a role amidst the tragedy of the Israel-Hamas war.

item.dc:creator: Daniel Estrin

item.title: Did a letter written by Osama bin Laden really go viral on TikTok this week?
item.description: Videos praising a letter written by Al Qaeda founder Osama Bin Laden briefly circulated on TikTok this week. But the reaction exceeded the reach of the videos themselves.

content:encoded.#cdata-section: Videos praising a letter written by Al Qaeda founder Osama Bin Laden briefly circulated on TikTok this week. But the reaction exceeded the reach of the videos themselves.
